text: Any fans of tiling window managers here? That's tiling window managers (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tiling_window_manager>) in contrast to stacking window managers (<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stacking_window_manager>). I've read a bunch from people who love using them around online. But I haven't found anyone who can convincingly describe why they prefer them. Most people talk about how they are easier to control from the keyboard, but that seems to stem from them being customizable, not from them tiling windows. I.e., what differentiates a tiling window manager is that for example if you have two windows next to each other, and you make one of them larger, it will simultaneously make the other one smaller. I'd love to hear from people who prefer tiling windows over stacking windows what they consider the advantages to be.

attachments.title: Tiling window manager
attachments.text: In computing, a tiling window manager is a window manager with an organization of the screen into mutually non-overlapping frames, as opposed to the more popular approach of coordinate-based stacking of overlapping objects (windows) that tries to fully emulate the desktop metaphor.

attachments.title: Stacking window manager
attachments.text: A stacking window manager (also called floating window manager) is a window manager that draws all windows in a specific order, allowing them to overlap, using a technique called painter's algorithm. All window managers that allow the overlapping of windows but are not compositing window managers are considered stacking window managers, although it is possible that not all use exactly the same methods. Other window managers that are not considered stacking window managers are those that do not allow the overlapping of windows, which are called tiling window managers.Stacking window managers allow windows to overlap by drawing them one at a time. Stacking, or repainting (in reference to painter's algorithm) refers to the rendering of each window as an image, painted directly over the desktop, and over any other windows that might already have been drawn, effectively erasing the areas that are covered. The process usually starts with the desktop, and proceeds by drawing each window and any child windows from back to front, until finally the foreground window is drawn.The order in which windows are to be stacked is called their z-order.

text: I am stuck on i3 and never really customized it after the first 2 weeks of 4 years.  Using the keyboard and switching tasks/context save time for me.

I don't think I often change window sizes.  I move things around workspaces, make one fullscreen (this slack is now), put it back in its spot, so it's more about overview vs focus, if that makes sense.
and organizing things in familiar places wrt multiple monitors so I can get to them quickly.

I especially like it when I am working on different projects that require different tooling and IDEs.  Some emacs users try to use emacs for absolutely everything including window-management for similar reasons.

Thanks for the answer! Do you any of the feature you're describing necessitate tiling windows? When I read through the advantages they all seem like they would work fine with a stacking window manager?

so, workspace 1 is all my comms and browsers, 2 is emacs and some terminals, 4 is VS code and some terminals for C# right now, 10 is where I dismiss terminals I don't actually want to read, like launching some UI with logs in the background.
Yeah, I use macOS with its default window manager, and I have different workspaces with different apps, etc...
I don't want it stacked, since I want to see everything in a logical chunk, not overlapping windows.
if there is information that can get hidden, then I don't want to see it at all
would prefer to make the window smaller and make more room for something else
it's not usually corners that matter, I guess :slightly_smiling_face:
I could get 80% of the way there on macos, but had to abandon it.
Just to push further, I have it setup so I can resize windows to half and half (or whatever configuration) with keyboard shortcuts. What do you think makes the tiling approach better than that?
I never do half and half
Yeah particular configurationss aren't important
I happen to do half and half, but you cna configure any way you want
I think I prefer 3 windows per workspace
two on top of each other on the left, and narrow, and one big one on the right
Yeah you could just setup a stacking window manager to have a shortcut for left/center/right, how would you compare that to the tiling approach?
the things that are missing for my common case are easy fullscreen toggle for any window, and vertical vs horizontal layout switches.

Full screen is easy with a stacking window manager, but vertical vs. horizontal (if you mean swap these three horizontal columns to three horizontal rows), that would be really difficult with stacking window manager
Just out of curiosity is there a particular point in your workflow that you tend to make that switch?
yea, but like I said, it's always 2 and 1, like [-][ ]
with the left column narrower
I think I'm missing something, why doesn't "have a shortcut for left/center/right" cover that?
left center right is [ ][ ][ ]
Oh the individual size for each shortcut is customizable
SO [    ] [ ] [ ] is no problem
but then my terminals are needlessly tall and narrow :slightly_smiling_face:
Ok I'm still missing something then :slightly_smiling_face:
PRobably I still don't understand this: "yea, but like I said, it's always 2 and 1, like [-][ ] "
E.g., I would interpret 2 and 1 as `[ ][ ][   ]`, but it sounds like you mean something different?
And I don't know what the hyphen means in `[-][ ]`?
something like this
two vertically stacked terminals on the left, one big more UI-y thing on the right
Got it, yeah you could do that with a stacking window manager and shortcuts too.
Shortcuts for upper left, lower left, and right
windows 10 gets pretty close, but it's powerful with hotkeys for resizing and moving windows between workspaces, and also focus follows mouse.

When you get that complex it's better to have a shortcut system, rather than shortcuts for a specific size, but I think that's the same between stacking vs. tiling window managers, e.g., there's nothing inherent about tiling windows that makes keyboard-driven resizing easier
It's just whether when you resizing, whether the other windows are also simultaneously resized that distinguishes a tiling window manager
right, I just never want to resize one window over top of another
Yeah this gets sort of to, my real question, which is why not? :slightly_smiling_face:
so every resize becomes two resizes?
Unless I do that, when I change focus, it overlaps and hides some information from the other window until I do one more thing.
i3 also supports tabs within a container, but I never use them
I'm a bit confused about the line "when I change focus, it overlaps and hides some information"? Changing focus doesn't resize itself?
if I resize window 1 to overlap window 2, which I click into window 2, suddenly window 2 is on top of parts of window 1, and I can't see them unless I a) resize again or b) refocus to window 1 again.
Do you automatically resize windows when you click into them?
not sure what you mean
Oh got it yeah, ok sorry misread
I guess as a counterpoint to myself, I do use tabs for browsers, because there's too much useless information across 30 windows.
Ok cool, I've gotten a lot out of this, summarizing the conversation I'd say it's something like: I prefer when resizing a window that I can still see all the information in the other windows.
Yeah, browsers are the elephant in the room with tiling window managers I feel like. Browsers are just crap at resizing
Browsers work great at mobile size, and work great at full screen laptop size, but are garbage at everything in between
Cool, yeah this was super helpful, thanks for responding!
And if you have any suggestions to improve this summary, I'd love to hear it: "I prefer when resizing a window that I can still see all the information in the other windows."
how about: Hierarchical tiling WMs just give you more of why you like workspaces?
Maybe it's a 'you have to experience it' thing

When you say "you have to experience it" what I hear is "it's what I'm used to" :slightly_smiling_face: Preferences are great, but if I can't articulate what the specific advantage is, I assume it's just that, a preference rather than an advantage
I'm curious about the workspaces thing though, how would you describe the connection to tiling wm and workspaces?
E.g., from my perspective a workspace is just a bucket of windows, don't see how whether they are stacked or tiled windows matters?
Everything is a tree of containers, workspaces are the top level nodes. Containers determine the layout.

(And just to be clear, when resizing a window, that you don't hide information on other windows, is just a cold hard advantage of tiling window managers, that's exactly the type of thing I'm looking for)
so it helps you organize by use-case
That sounds like an implementation detail, not an inherent advantage?
I like to write outlines when I approach everything, so tree structures work for me :slightly_smiling_face:
E.g., on macOS I have a chat workspace, a programming workspace, a media workspace, etc... what's the connection to tiling windows?
The tree structure sounds like a cool configuration feature, which sounds great, is there a reason a stacking window manager couldn't have that same feature?
I think it's subtle, but think of your workspaces as tiles.
it's just that they are fixed to your screen size and there's usually a fixed number of them.
In a tiling wm, dimensions are entangled in a convenient way. I think someone mentioned that. In Windows, the entanglement breaks really easily. Workspaces seem orthogonal?
What makes the way they are entangled convenient?
Just as I can move windows between workspaces with a hotkey, I can push them into a subcontainer with a different layout just as easily.
That sounds like the same thing as shortcut for upper left, lower left and right, the tiling WM difference is just that it replaces rather than overlaps
hmm, the actions are more relative to the window you're focused on than that.

The way a refactoring tool is more convenient than making all the changes by hand, or the way moving things in a box is more convenient than carrying them one by one? :stuck_out_tongue: Lots of little reasons. I feel like people have touched on most of them already.
yea, it's a lot like paredit in lisp for me.
But with a refactoring tool, it's easy to quantify the advantage: Less key presses to get the same result

My summary after reading this exchange: tiling WMs provide mechanisms for resizing and also a very convenient, learnable _default policy_. Stacking WMs don't imposed a policy, and so to provide equivalent power in mechanisms need people to learn a lot more shortcuts.
Not sure on that, both policies seem equally learnable? Window stacks or window tiles?
And I haven't seen a reason you need less keyboard shortcuts with tiling?
By 'less keyboard shortcuts' do you mean fewer shortcuts, or fewer keypresses over common use-cases?
I am happy to learn more shortcuts for fewer keypresses
I mean fewer shortcuts, but fewer keypresses is also an interesting metric

I like the cognitive model of tiling WMs as trees. I wonder if someone has created a tiling WM with zoom in/out operations that go in/out of full screen without changing layout. You can zoom in to a single window, but can you zoom out to take in multiple workspaces?
What are the "common use-cases"? I can think of one, that's half/half, e.g., built-in to Windows. Are there others?
I think that explains our impasse a little for me.
It's a simpler cognitive model, nothing to do with how the WM is implemented.

root.text: That sounds like an implementation detail, not an inherent advantage?

text: For use-cases, I mentioned coarse-grained task switching (I'm on C# for a few hours, leave the python for a while), overview vs focus on a single window in a workspace (fullscreen, unfullscreen).
Being able to see all the information I need, so something about relevance and density.
<@UE0ETTCG7> it seems like you've already made up your mind :grin:
Actually I don't think I've argued any specific thing here
Frankly I don't have an opinion as I've never used one
If I had an opinion, I'd by listing reasons overlapping windows are better, honestly to me it just seems like personal preference, pros and cons to each
The only hard advantage to tiling wm I've seen is that when you resizing a window, it doesn't hide information in other windows. I'm jsut wondering if there are more advantages.
I use stacking WMs but it's useful to understand the trade-offs. Trade-offs involve what's easy vs what's hard. Repeatedly reductively saying "I can do that" closes your mind to that important axis.
To flip that around: All of these other arguments sound like you've learned to configure a tiling wm, but if you learned to configure a stacking wm, you'd see they are easy in teh model too
I have used stacking WMs far longer than tiling WMs, but I quickly became more effective with a tiling WM.  I think most people are more used to stacking WMs, but some switch to tiling WMs.

I want to switch from this one layout to this other layout. I got one key in a tiling manager. It either requires >1 key with a stacking manager or it requires me to first create and save layouts. The reason it's easier in a tiling WM: somebody curated the layouts I'm likely to want in advance

root.text: And I haven't seen a reason you need less keyboard shortcuts with tiling?

text: I've never used a tiling manager but these arguments make sense to me.

root.text: To flip that around: All of these other arguments sound like you've learned to configure a tiling wm, but if you learned to configure a stacking wm, you'd see they are easy in teh model too

text: Why do you think there's not curated layouts for stacking wms?
I don't have them. If you do, please provide a pointer.
Show me a stacking WM that I will like for reasons other than 'it gets close to a tiling WM' :smile:

I don't think there are, that's just another way of phrasing my whole point here: To go back to the beginning, most of the reason people list for prefering tiling wms is because they are configurable, not because they tile windows.
I think you're dismissing other arguments too quickly. May be worth thinking about them for a while.

root.text: To flip that around: All of these other arguments sound like you've learned to configure a tiling wm, but if you learned to configure a stacking wm, you'd see they are easy in teh model too

text: Which arguments?
PS I assure you I've been mulling this for epic lengths of time, the reason I started this thread is I just can't figure it out
TBH I couldn't make it work on OSX without a lot of effort.
I didn't feel it was worth it there.  I had to do a lot more 'configuring' to get anywhere and there was still too much remaining inconsistency.

If there's any value to asking the question, to get at it you'll need to stop typing for a while to think about the answers.

With that, I'll stop typing.

root.text: PS I assure you I've been mulling this for epic lengths of time, the reason I started this thread is I just can't figure it out

text: A bit more backstory: There is a nut job wm for macOS called Mjolnir <https://github.com/mjolnirapp/mjolnir> that I got pretty deep into, and that left me with question: This seems to do all the things that people talk about with tiling wms, but it doesn't actually require any "tiling" features. That was maybe three or four years ago, and I'm still trying to figure it out.
I got pretty far with this one: <https://github.com/koekeishiya/kwm>
but it's just inconsistent APIs with workspaces and general flakiness, and now it is abandoned.
Yeah, so maybe that's a better lien of questioning, why do you tiling wm better than kwm?
E.g., inconsistent APIs and flakiness have nothing to do with tiling
I think it's what I was trying to express earlier.  There's more consistency in i3's data model, and it can take more control of windowing, workspaces, and layout on linux than OSX allows.
eg: <https://github.com/mjolnirapp/mjolnir/issues/568>
Again, that's not about tiling, that just sounds like i3 is better designed than macOS window manager, which I'd agree 100% with
That is useful backstory. Stating it up front would have let to more useful discussion!

root.text: A bit more backstory: There is a nut job wm for macOS called Mjolnir <https://github.com/mjolnirapp/mjolnir> that I got pretty deep into, and that left me with question: This seems to do all the things that people talk about with tiling wms, but it doesn't actually require any "tiling" features. That was maybe three or four years ago, and I'm still trying to figure it out.

text: here's an issue I created: <https://github.com/koekeishiya/kwm/issues/596>
Mjolnir has the same maintenance problems at KWM no question
FYI, you don't even need software for this on macOS, I re-wrote Mjolnir in AppleScript <https://github.com/robenkleene/windowpane>
Because I realized the OS provides everything any of these applications do
of course it does, just more or less usefully
Just like 'java has lists, why use guava?'
But that was my whole point: Most arguments for why people use tiling wms is because they're easier to configure, not because they tile windows.

Sorry but thing just makes my head want to explode, for years I've been hearing people saying tiling wms are a huge productivity boost and then listing reasons (like easier to use from the keyboard and easier to configure) that have nothing to do with tiling windows. I know I have like some sort of problem that I sometimes drive people crazy pushing points like this, but I'm just trying to makes sure I understand correctly.

(And I'm not saying there aren't advantages to tiling wms automatically resizing other windows, it's just that seems to be a marginal feature to most people compared to the keyboard control and configuration features)

The disconnect may be that people are talking about existing product categories rather than platonic ideals.

I'm not sure anyone's ever made the claim that what tiling WMs are today strictly dominates what stacking WMs _could be_ in the best of all possible universes. That feels like a strawman.

Which is why I wish you had led with the product that improves on stacking WM state of the art. I got a lot out of this discussion, but I suspect you'd have gotten more if you'd done that. You'd have needed to repeat yourself less.

I'm definitely looking forward to trying out your AppleScript.
Ha don't use the AppleScript, I couldn't make it fast
I use keyboard meastro now, recommended unconditionally
<https://www.keyboardmaestro.com/main/>

attachments.title: Keyboard Maestro 9.0.1: Work Faster with Macros for macOS
attachments.text: Keyboard Maestro is the leading software for macOS automation. It will increase business productivity by using macros (or short cuts) with simple keystrokes.

text: (but paid)
Being easier to use with a keyboard, and easier to configure, do seem to stem directly from having a more constrained layout model (tiling).
<@UFEQUBNNT> Yeah I 100% agree, I just haven't been able to come up with an example myself that proves that. Every attempt I've tried I've been able to replicate with a stacking wm with no downside
Always excluding the inherent difference about the stacking or tiling itself, which I recognize as an advantage
When you replicate it, do you end up with something that's more like a tiling wm than what you started with, or do you end up somewhere new?

<@UE0ETTCG7> The very fact that you're replacing a window manager with an automation app suggests to me that you're not appreciating people's arguments here. Sure I could make stacking WMs do anything I want with a Turing-complete scripting language. That's not because of the stacking WM, it's because of the Turing-complete language.

Tiling WMs reduce the amount people need to mess with their WM. Adding a new way to mess with the WM doesn't address that advantage.
The allure of your AppleScript was that somebody else (i.e. you) has already done the messing about for me.
<@UFEQUBNNT> I would say I just get more shortcuts with a stacking wm, I wouldn't call it anything new. I don't see any distinction between what I do with a stacking wm and configuring a tiling wm
I'd call it _being burdened with_ more shortcuts.
Why aren't tiling wm shortcuts a burden? These are just preferences, some people like resizing with the mouse, some with shortcuts, live and let live
more shortcuts is worse in isolation, but it can be a net win depending on usage
as an emacs user, I don't learn 100x as many shortcuts as I do
if I notice something repetitive, it might inspire me to find a better way
I'm very conscious that my particular set of choices is some kind of local maxima

there's a saying from Runar Bjarnsson that "constraints liberate; liberties constrain". i've seen this play out in many different parts of life. for example, guitar is in some ways not as versatile as piano, but i find songwriting easier on guitar because it's easier to play within patterns. and sometime, ukulele is even easier to improvise on, despite being less powerful.

but on another topic, just as a suggestion, i try to be mindful of the extent to which i'm asking other people to do my thinking for me. as an outside observer, it reads a bit like you asking folks to drag you over the cognitive hill to get to the destination they reached on their own, while at the same time, being kind of resistant to getting there.

Shrug, I'm neutral on shortcuts, some people like them some don't. I was under the impression one of the reason people like tiling wms is they like the shortcuts. So I was curious how well those same shortcuts work with a stacking wm, from my perspective they seem to work well. Again we're totally in personal preference territory here, see Tog <https://www.asktog.com/TOI/toi06KeyboardVMouse1.html>
i3 in particular was very little customization away from stock for me, and I appreciate that.

<@UCUSW7WVD> To address your concerns, I've tried to keep move the discussion from implementation details of individual tiling wms to advantages inherent in the model. If there's a better way to do that, I'm happy to hear it. You already mentioned giving more back story in the beginning, which is feedback I'll factor in (although I was concerned about making a wall of text right of the bat).
Yeah great defaults is a *huge* feature
yea, I think that's the point we're all trying to make
Underappreciated in my opinion
(So surprised you like Emacs, *ducks*)
to be fair, I import a package called 'better-defaults'
Haha, yeah I think I do to
But `C-x 5 2` to open a new window...
emacs is a worse tiling WM than i3, but this exists: <https://technomancy.us/184>
I don't like emacs in principle, but it has sank its claws deep
I'm a huge fan of magit <https://magit.vc>

text: helm is a great analogy to this conversation, providing a consistent interface to a lot of scattered functionality. I also :heart: magit.

> Helm is an Emacs framework for incremental completions and narrowing selections. It helps to rapidly complete file names, buffer names, or any other Emacs interactions requiring selecting an item from a list of possible choices.
never thought I needed a completion and selection narrowing framework until I used it

To connect up with an earlier conversation, I wonder if these top-shelf Emacs plugins address Oleg Kiselyov's desires atop a regular file system: <https://futureofcoding.slack.com/archives/C5T9GPWFL/p1566430274337300>

attachments.fallback:
[August 21st, 2019 4:31 PM] ak: *File systems (and much else) should be databases* (1995)

<http://okmij.org/ftp/papers/DreamOSPaper.html>

> This paper is an attempt to imagine what an OS would look like and how it would work if looking for a word 'foo' in something and deleting/closing/stopping this something, -- be it a paragraph of text, a network connection, a subscribed newsgroup, a process -- would all require roughly the same sequence of mouse clicks or keystrokes, and would be understood and interpreted in the same spirit by the operating system.

> ASCII configuration files abound, for a very simple reason: they can be modified with any text editor from `ex` and `edlin` upwards, and can be viewed and created even without an editor, with a `cat` command.

These two paragraphs feel contradictory. Text files already provide roughly the same sequence of operations to update. Can anybody tell what the article expects the benefits of databases to be? I see something about the CPU cycles to parse text files. But that seems to perversely ignore the complexities of using a database.

Another take: your file system already has much that looks like a database with journalling and so on. Mission accomplished?

Personal note: I've looked at several papers this week and been tempted to go implement them. This is a big shift compared to the past 5 years, while I've been slowly putting the foundations of the Mu computer together. It feels like a weight has been lifted off my shoulders, and I can start prototyping new ideas again. Anybody want to play with adding a stupid database before a file system? The Mu computer currently has no access to its local file system, so we have a blank slate to play with.
attachments.text:
*File systems (and much else) should be databases* (1995)

<http://okmij.org/ftp/papers/DreamOSPaper.html>

> This paper is an attempt to imagine what an OS would look like and how it would work if looking for a word 'foo' in something and deleting/closing/stopping this something, -- be it a paragraph of text, a network connection, a subscribed newsgroup, a process -- would all require roughly the same sequence of mouse clicks or keystrokes, and would be understood and interpreted in the same spirit by the operating system.

> ASCII configuration files abound, for a very simple reason: they can be modified with any text editor from `ex` and `edlin` upwards, and can be viewed and created even without an editor, with a `cat` command.

These two paragraphs feel contradictory. Text files already provide roughly the same sequence of operations to update. Can anybody tell what the article expects the benefits of databases to be? I see something about the CPU cycles to parse text files. But that seems to perversely ignore the complexities of using a database.

Another take: your file system already has much that looks like a database with journalling and so on. Mission accomplished?

Personal note: I've looked at several papers this week and been tempted to go implement them. This is a big shift compared to the past 5 years, while I've been slowly putting the foundations of the Mu computer together. It feels like a weight has been lifted off my shoulders, and I can start prototyping new ideas again. Anybody want to play with adding a stupid database before a file system? The Mu computer currently has no access to its local file system, so we have a blank slate to play with.

text: git is a DB as far as I'm concerned
But helm (and fzf) has nothing to do with git. Really cool examples of how the Unix philosophy can sometimes accomodate UI elements.
It’s astounding to me how disjointed al the data on my machine is. Why can’t I get to all my data with a language like SQL?
I don’t understand why something like this hasn’t taken hold yet: <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WinFS>

attachments.title: WinFS
attachments.text:
WinFS (short for Windows Future Storage) was the code name for a canceled data storage and management system project based on relational databases, developed by Microsoft and first demonstrated in 2003 as an advanced storage subsystem for the Microsoft Windows operating system, designed for persistence and management of structured, semi-structured and unstructured data.
WinFS includes a relational database for storage of information, and allows any type of information to be stored in it, provided there is a well defined schema for the type. Individual data items could then be related together by relationships, which are either inferred by the system based on certain attributes or explicitly stated by the user. As the data has a well defined schema, any application can reuse the data; and using the relationships, related data can be effectively organized as well as retrieved. Because the system knows the structure and intent of the information, it can be used to make complex queries that enable advanced searching through the data and aggregating various data items by exploiting the relationships between them.

While WinFS and its shared type schema make it possible for an application to recognize the different data types, the application still has to be coded to render the different data types. Consequently, it would not allow development of a single application that can view or edit all data types; rather, what WinFS enables applications to do is understand the structure of all data and extract the information that they can use further. When WinFS was introduced at the 2003 Professional Developers Conference, Microsoft also released a video presentation, named IWish, showing mockup interfaces that showed how applications would expose interfaces that take advantage of a unified type system. The concepts shown in the video ranged from applications using the relationships of items to dynamically offer filtering options to applications grouping multiple related data types and rendering them in a unified presentation.
WinFS was billed as one of the pillars of the "Longhorn" wave of technologies, and would ship as part of the next version of Windows.  It was subsequently decided that WinFS would ship after the release of Windows Vista, but those plans were shelved in June 2006, with some of its component technologies being integrated into <http://ADO.NET|ADO.NET> and Microsoft SQL Server.

text: search is a powerful and complex approach, but I think trying to make a general approach for FSs is really hard.
I usually turn them off because they suck performance.
Or I guess, updating indexes in realtime is the horrible part.  CLI search tools like 'ag' are great.

I used to use `ag` but switched to `rg` <https://github.com/BurntSushi/ripgrep> That was initially because `ag` doesn't parse `gitignore` files correctly and `rg` does, but I've come to love `rg` also for its "design", i.e., it's CLI flags just seem perfect to me.

One funny bit on search in general is it's really weird to me that code editors often don't show results live when you start typing (e.g., like Google does). That feels like it should be a table stakes feature in 2019. Even more so when doing a find and replace. Having to hit enter to see whether I performed the replace correctly (instead of just seeing the transformation live) feels anachronistic
Thanks for the feedback Alan, sorry I missed this until just now. There's definitely something I struggle with here, but unfortunately I have no idea what to do differently.

I'd like to respond more but I don't know what else to say. I'd love to climb up that cognitive hill, and I swear I am not deliberately trying to avoid it (quite the opposite in fact, I've been researching window management for years), but unfortunately I guess I'm just not smart enough to see the steps. :man-shrugging:

Hi Roben, I use a tiling window manager (i3). The main thing I like is that default is to make everything visible on a workspace and use up all the available space. Consider the stacking window manager screenshot above where the file manger and minesweeper obscures the program manager. Further there are large chunks of spaces just left unused. If you often use 'adjustable aspect ratio' apps (e.g. terminals, editors browsers etc. work at different aspect ratios and sizes, maybe not minesweeper or clock), then filling up the screen and making all information visible is great. It doesn't matter if there's a shortcut in stacking WMs to snap to left-50% or right-50%. In i3, if I launch two terminal windows they're already snapped left and right taking 50% space each by default, no other shortcuts required. The automatic tiling is the main thing I like.
wish i had specific advice, other than  introspection. it helps me take a breath when i feel like the information flow isn't happening

<https://youtu.be/RTkxzQDo0ng> this is the craziest video on a video game i’ve ever watched. it involves a racing game where the protagonist is in a coma for the whole game and it’s only available on websites so sketchy that you can literally buy download codes with subway sandwich gift cards. not super related to coding except that i think we would see a lot more of this level of weirdness in computer art if programming were more accessible
